subject: Re: [junit] Re: Is there any way I can use a failed test invoke other function?
msgSnippet: I reinstalled my eclipse, it works now. Thank you a lot Jeff. ... __________________________________________________ Do You Yahoo!? Tired of spam?  Yahoo! Mail
messageBody:
I reinstalled my eclipse, it works now. Thank you a
lot Jeff.

--- Jeff Grigg <jeffgrigg@...> wrote:

> --- Tao Dong <tao_dong_cn@y...> wrote:
> > Thank you for your help Jeff. But even I overrided
> the
> > protected void runTest() throws Throwable
> > as you said, it doesn't work. I think maybe I
> don't
> > understand your method well.
> > [...]
>
> That's odd; it works for me. (Now that's a common,
> and annoying
> phrase! ;-)
>
> With JUnit 3.8.1 (Running under Eclipse 3.0.2)
>
> I run this:
>
> | import junit.framework.TestCase;
> | public class SimpleTest extends TestCase {
> | public void testAlwaysFalse() {
> | assertTrue(false);
> | }
> | public void testAlwaysTrue() {
> | assertTrue(true);
> | }
> | public void testAlwaysFails() {
> | fail("FailureMessage");
> | }
> | public void testAlwaysSucceeds() {
> | }
> | // @Override
> | protected void runTest() throws Throwable {
> | try {
> | System.out.println("Running test " +
> super.getName());
> | super.runTest();
> | System.out.println(" Test ran
> successfully.");
> | } catch (final Throwable thr) {
> | System.out.println(" Exception: " +
> thr.toString());
> | throw thr;
> | }
> | }
> | }
>
> and get this:
>
> | Running test testAlwaysFalse
> | Exception: junit.framework.AssertionFailedError
> | Running test testAlwaysTrue
> | Test ran successfully.
> | Running test testAlwaysFails
> | Exception: junit.framework.AssertionFailedError:
> FailureMessage
> | Running test testAlwaysSucceeds
> | Test ran successfully.
>
> I'm not running JUnit 4. But a quick glance at the
> source makes me
> think that this should still work in JUnit 4.
>
> I'm stuck; I don't see an obvious reason why this
> would fail for
> you. Maybe someone else has an idea?
>
>
>
